eagleObject.title: Simalos' epigram commentary (E1 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The commentary of the E1 epigram (in Voskos, 1997), known as the Simalos' epigram, is composed of 27 pages. The inscription tells us about Stolos the Athenean, that honours his Cypriot friend Simalos by dedicating a statue to the Delian Apollo.

eagleObject.title: Simalos' epigram - Modern Greek text (E1 in Voskos, 1997)

visualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Simalos' epigram - Modern Greek text (E1 in Voskos, 1997)

eagleObject.title: Simalos' epigram - Modern Greek text (E1 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description:
Stolos the Athenean honours his Cypriot friend Simalos by dedicating a statue to the Delian Apollo. Ὁ Στόλος Θέωνος ὁ Ἀθηναῖος ὁ μέγας ἀξιωματοῦχος τοῦ βασιλιᾶ Πτολεμαίου τοῦ δευτέρου Σωτῆρος (τὸ ἄγαλμα ποὺ παριστάνει) τὸν Σίμαλο Τιμάρχου τὸν Σαλαμίνιο, τὸν δικό του φίλο, (ἀφιερώνει) στὸν Ἀπόλλωνα.
Μὲ τοῦ Ἀλκίνοου τ' ἀνάκτορα παρόμοια μέγαρα σὺ ποὺ κατοικεῖς, Σίμαλε, τῆς ἀπροσποίητης δεῖγμα φιλοξενίας, ἁπλὲ καὶ στοὺς λόγους καὶ στὸν βίο τὸν περικαλλῆ, προσφιλὲς στῆς Αἰγύπτου τοὺς βασιλιάδες καταφύγιο καὶ στῆς Ρώμης τοὺς ὑπάτους καὶ στὴν Ἀττικὴ τοῦ Κέκροπα τὴ γῆ καὶ στῆς Δήλου τοὺς κατοίκους πολυσέβαστε, εἴθε στοὺς χρόνους κείνους νὰ σὲ γεννοῦσε ἡ πατρίδα ἡ ποθητή, τῶν Τρώων καὶ τῶν Δαναῶν ὅταν τραγούδαγε τὶς μάχες ὁ Μαιονίδης, τὴ δική σου εὐφροσύνη νὰ ἀτενίσει χρυσὸ μέσ' στὰ βιβλία μνημεῖο λόγου ἀνεγείροντας· τῶν Φαιάκων ἔτσι ὁ βασιλιὰς τόση δὲν θά 'παιρνε τὴ δόξα ὅπως σύ, ποὺ σπιτικὸ φιλόξενο στοὺς πάντες πρόσφερες. τοῦ Ἀντισθένη ἀπὸ τὴν Πάφο

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

visualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Philios' epigram - Modern Greek text (E11 in Voskos, 1997)

eagleObject.title: Philios' epigram - Modern Greek text (E11 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The funerary epigram is dedicated to Philios, Cypriot from Salamis and son of Ariston. Στὸν ὕπνο του ὁ Φίλιος, Κύπριος τὸ γένος ἀπὸ τὴ Σαλαμίνα, γιὸς τοῦ Ἀρίστωνα, τὸν Ναύλοχο εἶδε σ' ὄνειρο καὶ τὶς ἁγνὲς τὶς Θεσμοφόρες τὶς σεβάσμιες μέσ' στὰ λευκὰ τὰ ροῦχα· σ' ὁράματα τριπλὰ τὸν ἥρωα ἐτοῦτον νὰ τιμᾶ πρότρεπαν ὡς φύλακα τῆς πόλης καὶ χῶρον ὑποδεῖξαν· ἕνεκα τούτων ἀφιέρωσεν αὐτὸν ἐδῶ τὸν θεὸν ὁ Φίλιος.

eagleObject.title: Golgi's votive relief inscription - Ancient Greek text (E6 in Voskos, 1997)

visualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Golgi's votive relief inscription - Ancient Greek text (E6 in Voskos, 1997)

eagleObject.title: Golgi's votive relief inscription - Ancient Greek text (E6 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The Golgi's votive relief inscription is a funerary epigram with reflections on mortality, where it is shown the contrast between god's omnipotence and human weakness.

artifact.decoration: the relief represents a seated olympian zeus with scepter and thunderbolt. a musician playing lyre stands on the right and behind the high throne there is a smaller figure, perhaps his son. the scene is completed by a chariot drawn by winged horses, represented suspended in the air to the rear behind a small figure.

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

eagleObject.title: Sosipatra's epigram - image (E33 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The old image represents the epigram E33 (in Voskos, 1997) that is dedicated to Sosipatra. She speaks in first person and tells that she died young and unmarried. She says that she was cut away like a twig of olive tree for the wind gusts and far from her homeland. She wishes the passer by to die at a very old age.

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

eagleObject.description: The funerary epigram E18b (in Voskos, 1997) from Marion is dedicated from a father to his son

eagleObject.title: Glefkita's epigram transliteration image (E4 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: Glefkita's epigram image (E4 in Voskos, 1997). The inscription is a funerary epigram in honor of Glefkita from Salamis (Cyprus) and dedicated by Diotima

artifact.stateOfPreservation: it remains a full line, and a second one incomplete until the cesura of the third trochee

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Idagygos'epigram - Ancient Greek text (E3 in Voskos, 1997)

eagleObject.title: Idagygos'epigram - Ancient Greek text (E3 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: This is an epigram in honor of Idagygos from Alikarnassos who died fighting in Cyprus and then was buried in Amathus

artifact.stateOfPreservation: fairly good. with the exception of the final letter a (with only a small trace left), the inscription is not displayed trouble reading and understanding, especially since almost all words are separated with relatively symbol (:)

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

inscription.honorand: Idagygos from Alikarnassos, mercenary among Ionian Warriors
inscription.relatedEvent: Honouring the fall of his son in battle

eagleObject.title: Kilika's epigram - image details (E24 in Voskos, 1997)

visualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation / Museum Pieridis, Larnaca

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Kilika's epigram - image details (E24 in Voskos, 1997)
hasArtifact.objectType: quadrilateral stele composed of a base and a trunk

eagleObject.title: Kilika's epigram - image details (E24 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The old image represents the inscription details of the the funerary epigram E24 (Voskos, 1997). Kilika from Kition, died at the age of forty, asks the passer by to stop in order to learn about his life.

artifact.objectType: quadrilateral stele composed of a base and a trunk
artifact.decoration: an embossed wreath dominates, from the top to the middle, the trunk, and underneath until nearly the end of the trunk is the epigram

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation / Museum Pieridis, Larnaca

eagleObject.title: Nicocreon's epigram - Modern Greek text (E9 in Voskos, 1997)

visualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Nicocreon's epigram - Modern Greek text (E9 in Voskos, 1997)

eagleObject.title: Nicocreon's epigram - Modern Greek text (E9 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The funerary epigram E9 (in Voskos, 1997) is dedicated to the king of Salamis Nicocreon, son of Pnytagoras and Aiakos descendant, and it speaks in first person. Μητρόπολή μου ἡ γῆ τοῦ Πέλοπα τὸ Ἄργος τὸ Πελασγικό, Πνυταγόρας ὁ πατέρας μου τοῦ Αἰακοῦ ἀπὸ τὴ γενιά· εἶμαι ὁ Νικοκρέων, καὶ μ' ἔθρεψε γῆ θαλασσόζωστη ἡ Κύπρος ἀπὸ θεϊκότατους προγόνους βασιλιά. Μὲ στῆσαν οἱ Ἀργεῖοι γιὰ τὸν χαλκὸ τιμὴ ἀποτίοντας ποὺ στὴ γιορτὴ τῆς Ἥρας ἔστελλα γιὰ ἔπαθλα στοὺς νέους.

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

eagleObject.title: Epigram for a wife - Ancient Greek text (E30 in Voskos, 1997)

visualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Epigram for a wife - Ancient Greek text (E30 in Voskos, 1997)

eagleObject.title: Epigram for a wife - Ancient Greek text (E30 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The epigram E30 (in Voskos, 1997) is dedicated to a wife by her husband. The woman is compared for love and affection to famous women of the mithology, overpassing all of them. The husband says that even if now she is dead, he meets her often in his dreams. The man greets his wife saying that he will never forget her and he still desires her.

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

visualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation / Department of Antiquities, Cyprus

eagleObject.title: Pasicrates’(?) epigram - image (E16 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The funerary epigram E16 (in Voskos, 1997) is probably addressed to Pasicrates, the king of Soloi. The inscription tells that he had excellent children and lived his life in virtue.

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation / Department of Antiquities, Cyprus

inscription.paleographicCharacteristics: Capital lettersLeft to rightAlphabetic4 lines. The first half of all the lines has been lost. Various scholars attempted to restore the lost lines

eagleObject.description: The commentary of the E30 epigram (in Voskos, 1997), known as the funerary epigram for a wife, is composed of 6 pages. The inscription is dedicated to a wife by her husband. The woman is compared for love and affection to famous women of the mithology, overpassing all of them. The husband says that even if now she is dead, he meets her often in his dreams. The man greets his wife saying that he will never forget her and he still desires her.

eagleObject.title: Androcles' epigram - commentary (E15 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The commentary of the E15 epigram (in Voskos, 1997), also known as the Androcles' epigram, is composed of 5 pages. The epigram is a dedication of the king Androcles to Aphrodite together with a treasure and the image of his son Orestheos.

hasArtifact.artifactTitle: Stasioikos' epigram - Modern Greek text (E31 in Voskos, 1997)

eagleObject.title: Stasioikos' epigram - Modern Greek text (E31 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The epigram E31 (in Voskos, 1997) is dedicated to Stasioikos, who died at the entrance of Axeinos Pontos, before getting married and leaving his parents in tears and pain. Τὸν Στασίοικο ποὺ τῆς ζωῆς συμπλήρωσε, περαστικέ, τὸν κύκλο κάτω ἀπ' τὴ στήλη τὴ λιτὴ οἰκτρὸς νὰ κεῖται βλέπεις. Πλέοντας ὁ δύστυχος πρὸς τοῦ Ἄξεινου τὸ στόμα Πόντου μακρυὰ τῶν Μοιρῶν ξετέλεψα τὸ νῆμα, οὔτε γάμο οὔτ' ὑμέναιο βλέποντας γλυκύ, μὰ στοὺς γονεῖς δάκρυα καὶ φοβεροὺς τῶν κοπετῶν ἀφήνοντας τοὺς πόνους. Καμμιὰ δὲν βρῆκαν τοῦ κακοῦ παρηγοριὰ στὸν θρῆνο, π' ἀντὶ θαλάμου νυφικοῦ τὸν τάφο τώρα ἔχουν τοῦ παιδιοῦ τους. Ἀλλ' ἐμὲ τῶν πόνων λήθη περικάλυψε, οἰκτρὰ δὲ πένθη στὸν Θεόδοτο ἔχουν ἁπλωθῆ τὸν δύσμοιρο πατέρα.

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation

eagleObject.title: Epigram for a Cypriot woman - Ancient Greek text (E32 in Voskos, 1997)
eagleObject.description: The image shows the epigram E32 (in Voskos, 1997) that is dedicated to a Cypriot woman from Kekropidis. It is engraved on a marble slab that was found near the church of Chrysopolitissa in Nea Paphos.

artifact.stateOfPreservation: amputation of the inscription on the left side and on the upper part of the right side

originDating.period: End of the Ptolemaic period or early Roman period

findingSpot.modernFindSpot: Nea Paphos, near the church of Chrysopolitissa

conservationPlace.conservationCity: Archaeological Museum of the Paphos district

hasVisualRepresentation.visualRepresentationIpr: The Cyprus Institute - STARC / The A.G. Leventis Foundation / Department of Antiquities, Cyprus

inscription.paleographicCharacteristics: Small distance between the letters, the second line has smaller letters4
